sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Folic acid deficiency: up to 1 mg/day IM, IV, ORAL, SC; resistant cases may require larger doses
  • Folic acid deficiency: maintenance, 0.4 mg/day ORALLY; for pregnant and lactating women, 0.8 mg/day ORALLY; never less than 0.1 mg/day
  • Homocystinemia: 0.5 to 5 mg/day ORALLY
  • Megaloblastic anemia: up to 1 mg/day IM, IV, ORAL, SC; resistant cases may require larger doses
  • Megaloblastic anemia: maintenance, 0.4 mg/day ORAL, for pregnant and lactating women, 0.8 mg/day; never less than 0.1 mg/day
  • Pregnancy vitamin/iron prophylaxis: 0.4 mg to 1 mg ORALLY per day
  • Recommended dietary allowance: men, 400 mcg/day; women, 400 mcg/day; pregnancy 600 mcg/day; lactation, 500 mcg/day ORALLY
  • Toxicity of drug, Methotrexate: 5 to 27.5 mg/wk ORALLY

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Folic acid deficiency: ORAL, IM, IV, SC, up to 1 mg/day; resistant cases may require larger doses
  • Folic acid deficiency: maintenance, infants, 0.1 mg/day; age under 4 y, up to 0.3 mg/day; age 4 y or older, 0.4 mg/day
  • Megaloblastic anemia: ORAL, IM, IV, SC, up to 1 mg/day; resistant cases may require larger doses
  • Megaloblastic anemia: maintenance, infants, 0.1 mg/day; age under 4 y, up to 0.3 mg/day; age 4 y or older, 0.4 mg/day
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 1 y and younger, 65 to 80 mcg/day; 1 to 3 y, 150 mcg/day; 4 to 8 y, 200 mcg/day; 9 to 13 y, 300 mcg/day; 14 to 18 y, 400 mcg/d ORALLY

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• alcoholism, hemolytic anemia: maintenance dose may need to be increased
  • anticonvulsant therapy, chronic infection: maintenance dose may need to be increased

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Megaloblastic anemia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Age-related cognitive decline; Prophylaxis
  • Antiepileptic adverse reaction - Folic acid deficiency
  • Folic acid deficiency
  • Folic acid deficiency - Sex hormones adverse reaction
  • Homocystinemia
  • Pregnancy vitamin/iron prophylaxis
  • Recommended dietary allowance
  • Toxicity of drug, Methotrexate

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• folic acid doses above 0.1 mg/day may obscure pernicious anemia (hematologic remission while neurological manifestations progress)
  • pernicious anemia and other megaloblastic anemias caused by vitamin B12 deficiency

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Bad taste in mouth, Large doses, Loss of appetite, Nausea
  • Neurologic:Confusion
  • Psychiatric:Irritability, Sleep pattern disturbance
Serious
Immunologic:Allergic condition

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Folic acid, after conversion to tetrahydrofolic acid, is necessary for normal erythropoiesis , synthesis of purine and thymidylates , metabolism of amino acids such as glycine and methionine, and the metabolism of histidine.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Systemic: Hepatic: Active metabolite: tetrahydrofolic acid

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement, CBC, serum folate
  • (injection) aluminum toxicity; in renal impairment and premature neonates

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Injection Solution: 5 MG/ML
    • Oral Capsule: 5 MG, 20000 MCG
    • Oral Tablet: 0.4 MG, 0.8 MG, 1 MG, 800 MCG
  • FA-8
    Oral Capsule: 800 MCG
  • Folacin-800
    Oral Tablet: 0.8 MG
  • Methylfolate
    Oral Capsule: 2000 MCG
  • Nature's Blend Folic Acid
    Oral Tablet: 1 MG
  • Optimum Folic Acid
    Oral Tablet: 800 MCG
  • PharmAssure Folic Acid
    Oral Tablet: 0.4 MG, 0.8 MG
  • Rite Aid Folic Acid
    Oral Tablet: 0.4 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause loss of appetite, nausea, confusion, irritability, or sleep-pattern disturbance. Large doses of drug may cause bad taste in mouth.
  • Patient should not drink alcohol while taking this drug.
